comment.author: 62760997@N05
comment._content: I believe this is the last lighthouse on the Thames, now used as a Community Centre. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

comment.author: 57898942@N03
comment._content: The large structure suspended from the lantern roof are the arms of the explosive fog signal apparatus. Tonite charges would be suspended at the ends of these two arms and the whole structure wound up into the vertical position above the lantern roof. The charges would then be detonated in turn from inside the lantern at predetermined intervals. Afterwards, the arms would be wound down and the process repeated.

comment.author: 57898942@N03
comment._content: The lighthouse was built in 1846 at the junction of the River Lea and the River Thames. As well as it's training function, the lighthouse was also used to test lighting equipment and was collocated with Trinity House's maintenance depot; Trinity House being the authority responsible for maintaining lighthouses around the coast of England and Wales.
